name: Section 1 - Organization and Management System (ORG)
applicability:
Applicability
Section 1 addresses the organization and management system of an operator for the purpose of ensuring
the safety and security of aircraft operations.
Individual ORG provisions or sub-specifications within an ORG provision that:
 Do not begin with a conditional phrase are applicable to all operators unless determined otherwise
by the Auditor.
 Begin with a conditional phrase ( If the Operator... ) are applicable if the operator meets the
condition(s) stated in the phrase.
Many ORG provisions are repeated in one or more other sections of the ISM (as indicated by the  
symbol). Refer to the IOSA Audit Handbook for information relevant to the proper internal auditing of
repeated ORG ISARPs.
ORG 2.1.4 in this section is applicable only to an operator that is currently on the IOSA Registry and is
being audited for the purpose of registration renewal.
guidance:
General Guidance
Definitions of technical terms used in this ISM Section 1 , as well as the meaning of abbreviations and
acronyms are found in the IATA Reference Manual for Audit Programs (IRM).
1 Management and Control
1.1 Management System Overview

items.paragraph: The Operator shall have a management system that has continuity throughout the organization an nsures control of operations and management of safety and security outcomes. ( GM)

The Operator shall designate a manager who is responsible for the implementation, maintenanc nd day-to-day administration of the SMS throughout the organization on behalf of the AE and senio anagement.
The Operator shall have an SMS that is implemented and integrated throughout the organization t nsure management of the safety risks associated with aircraft operations.

The Operator shall have a policy that informs operational personnel throughout the organization o heir responsibility to comply with the applicable laws, regulations and procedures in all location here operations are conducted.

The Operator shall have a process or procedure for the delegation of duties within the managemen ystem that ensures managerial continuity is maintained when operational managers including, i pplicable, post holders are unable to carry out work duties.

The Operator shall ensure a delegation of authority and assignment of responsibility within th anagement system for liaison with regulatory authorities, original equipment manufacturers an ther operationally relevant external entities.

The Operator shall have processes for setting safety performance indicators (SPIs) and, a pplicable, safety performance targets (SPTs) as means to monitor its safety performance, th chievement of its safety objectives and to validate the effectiveness of safety risk controls.
The Operator shall ensure existence of the facilities, workspace, equipment and supportin ervices, as well as work environment, necessary to satisfy operational safety and securit equirements.

The Operator shall have a selection process for management and non-management positions withi he organization that require the performance of functions relevant to the safety or security of aircraf perations. Such process shall ensure candidates are selected on the basis of knowledge, skills,
training and experience appropriate for the position.

The Operator shall ensure personnel who perform functions relevant to the safety or security o ircraft operations are required to maintain competence on the basis of continued education an raining and, if applicable for a specified position, continue to satisfy any mandatory technica ompetency requirements.
The Operator should have a policy that requires personnel who perform operational functions critica o the safety of aircraft operations to be physically and medically fit for duty.

The Operator should have a procedure to ensure screening or testing for psychoactive substances i erformed on prospective operational personnel, unless such screening or testing is performed o rohibited by the State.

The Operator shall have processes to ensure a contract or agreement is executed with externa ervice providers that conduct outsourced operational functions for the Operator. Such contract o greement shall identify specific documented requirements that can be monitored by the Operator t nsure the safety and/or security of operations are being fulfilled by the service provider.

The Operator shall have a corporate emergency response plan (ERP) for the central managemen nd coordination of all activities necessary to respond to a major aircraft accident or other type o dverse event that results in fatalities, serious injuries, considerable damage and/or a significan isruption of aircraft operations.
The Operator shall have a designated manager with appropriate qualifications and authority t anage and be responsible for the development, implementation and maintenance of the corporat RP.

If the Operator has individual departmental or station emergency response plans within th rganization, the Operator shall ensure such individual plans are coordinated with the overal orporate emergency response plan under the ERP manager.

The Operator shall ensure the ERP as specified in ORG 1.7.1 includes provisions for the appropriat oordination with the emergency response plans of other applicable organizations relevant to th articular event or crisis.
The Operator shall have published procedures and assigned responsibilities to ensure a coordinate xecution of the corporate ERP.

The Operator shall have a process in the ERP to provide an accurate manifest to the appropriat uthorities in the event of an aircraft accident. Such manifest shall list crew members, passenger nd cargo, to include dangerous goods.
The Operator should ensure all personnel with responsibilities under the ERP are appropriatel rained and qualified to execute applicable procedures.
The Operator should have a process for a detailed debriefing and critique whenever the ERP i xecuted, either as a rehearsal or in response to an actual event.

The Operator should have the ready availability of a facility for use as an emergency managemen enter (EMC) with sufficient space, furnishings and equipment to successfully manage the executio f the corporate ERP.
The Operator should have procedures under the corporate ERP that ensure a central coordinatio nd control of all communications with external entities.

items.paragraph: If the Operator uses an electronic system for the management and control of records, the Operato hall ensure the system provides for a scheduled generation of backup record files.

The Operator shall have a hazard identification program that is implemented and integrate hroughout the organization and includes a combination of reactive and proactive methods of hazar dentification.

The Operator should have a confidential safety reporting system that is implemented throughout th rganization in a manner that encourages and facilitates the reporting of events, hazards and/o oncerns resulting from or associated with human performance in operations.
The Operator should have a program for the systematic acquisition and analysis of data fro bservations of flight crew performance during normal line operations.

The Operator shall have a process to identify changes within or external to the organization that hav he potential to affect the level of safety risks associated with aircraft operations, and to manage risk hat may arise from or are affected by such changes in accordance with ORG 3.1.1 andORG 3.2.1 .
The Operator should have a process for safety data analysis with the purpose of predicting futur isks associated with hazards to aircraft operations.

If the Operator conducts flights with aircraft that have a maximum certified takeoff mass in excess o 7,000 kg (59,525 lb), the Operator shall have a flight data analysis (FDA) program that requires  ystematic download and analysis of electronically recorded flight data from applicable aircraft in it leet. The FDA program shall be non-punitive and be integrated in the Operator s SMS.
The Operator should have a flight data analysis (FDA) program in accordance with ORG 3.3.1 that i pplied to aircraft in its fleet with a certified takeoff mass in excess of 20 000 kg (44,092 lb).

If the Operator has an FDA program in accordance with ORG 3.3.1 , the Operator shall hav rocesses to ensure program findings (e.g. hazards, adverse events and trends, airworthines ssues) are coordinated with relevant operational areas of the organization for further validation an ssessment, and for a determination of appropriate follow-up action. Such coordination and follow-u ction shall be accomplished within the SMS as follows:

	(i) Hazard identification and safety risk assessment and mitigation in accordance with OR .1.1 andORG 3.2.1 .

	(ii) Event investigation in accordance with ORG 3.5.1 andORG 3.5.2 .

	(iii) Continuing airworthiness assessment in accordance with Maintenance Managemen anual (MMM) procedures as specified in MNT 1.7.1 andTable 4.3 .
The Operator shall have a process for the investigation of aircraft accidents and incidents, to includ eporting of events in accordance with requirements of the State.

The Operator shall have a process for identifying and investigating irregularities and other non-
routine operational occurrences that might be precursors to an aircraft accident or incident.

The Operator should ensure critical information and communications technology systems and dat sed in operations and maintenance functions are identified and, in accordance with ris anagement principles, appropriate measures are developed and implemented to protect them fro nlawful interference.
The Operator shall have a process to ensure significant issues arising from quality assurance an isk management are subject to management review in accordance with ORG 4.1.1 .
The Operator shall have processes to monitor and assess its SMS processes in order to maintain o ontinually improve the overall effectiveness of the SMS.

The Operator shall have a program that ensures its personnel are trained to understand SM esponsibilities and competent to perform associated duties. The scope of such training shall b ppropriate to each individual s involvement in the SMS.

If the Operator outsources operational functions to external service providers, the Operator shoul ave a program that ensures personnel of external service providers are trained to understand SM esponsibilities and perform associated duties. The scope of such training should be appropriate t ndividual involvement in the Operator s SMS.

The Operator should demonstrate that systems, processes and procedures specified in the ISARP dentified with the [Eff] symbol are achieving the designated Desired Outcome.
Note: Conformity with this ORG provision is possible only when the Operator demonstrate ffectiveness of implementation for all ISARPs designated with the [Eff] symbol.
Note: Conformity with this provision does not require specifications to be documented by th perator.
